post.title: Markets Live: Wednesday, 30th September, 2015
post.content:
This Markets Live session ended at 12:05 on 30 Sep 2015. Participants in this session were: Bryce Elder

BE

Hello, hi there, welcome to the end of the quarter.

BE

The good news is that we have power, unlike yesterday.

BE

There was a big powercut in Southwark at about 4pm, which switched us to emergency backup.

BE

But the powercut triggered an evacuation of the office, so we lost an hour standing around in the Lloyds car park next door.

BE

Then when we got back into the office, the power was restored at about 6pm

BE

….. which meant the emergency backup was switched off, and all the computers went dead for 20 minutes.

BE

Great, huh? Still managed to get a newspaper out though.

BE

Anyway, all that has reminded me of what you can buy these days for $390m.

BE

BE

BE

Go on, give them some traffic …..

BE

http://www.busines…-strip-2014-1?IR=T

BE

Because traffic is their reason for being.

BE

And, yeah, I know it’s yesterday’s news. But perhaps we can just take another glance over the Axel-Insider numbers.

BE

As in, publisher acquiring €7m of EBITDA losses

BE

For circa 7-9 times its 2015 sales, or six times forecast 2016

BE

And about 85 per cent of those sales are advertising. Online advertising.

BE

All funded by a €400m term loan, bringing Axel’s leverage to 2.2x

BE

And diluting EPS by around 4%

BE

Those are just the facts. I make no editorial comment on these facts.

BE

Instead, here’s Barclays.

BE

Overall, we see a much weaker returns profile for acquisitions of this kind than for online classified sites. And we would have far more confidence on the 5-year progress of another online classified business, with a strong market position.
Though Business Insider has big traffic, it is difficult to build confidence that it will be an important site in 5 years’ time. Of course it may well grow as suggested, but there have to be risks from competition and “consumer taste” in that timeframe.
Overall, we think that Axel management would need to have a very good success with Business Insider in order to fully convince investors that this new direction is a good idea.

BE

And here’s Deutsche.

BE

To start with the positives: AS management is clearly putting their money where their mouth is, expanding aggressively into digital content (to counter-balance the structural demise of its print business). Moreover, the total acquisition price is below what had been mooted in the press (c. USD 560m) and in line with implied valuations for other digital media assets (e.g. Vice Media, Buzzfeed). We concede that Business Insider has a strong growth trajectory backed by a distribution model geared towards mobile and social and with a focus on structurally growing ad formats such as video and native. Moreover, 30% of ad revenues (c. 85% of total sales) are sold via programmatic engines. We also agree that management has built a “proven” model as BI would have been break-even without investments in new verticals, i.e. “Tech Insider” and “Insider”.

BE

However, as expected, in the CC there was no mention of synergies between AS and BI, except for higher reach (combined, AS / BI are the 6th largest digital publisher globally by reach); in fact, Henry Blodget (CEO and Editor in Chief) mentioned that “BI does not like to be integrated”. Moreover, we note that BI management was not able to come up with a good answer as to “why sell now if growth prospects are that bright”. This naturally triggers the question whether such a deal will add value for AS shareholders, especially in light of underlying risks around the successful expansion into new verticals (where competition from other digital media is fierce) and new geographies outside the US (despite the launch in selected countries). Moreover, the sustainability of current trends in media consumption is not proven, and we note the rise of ad blockers in online advertising as a potential risk. Lastly, we flag that there was increasing criticism/allegations in the industry around Business Insiders’ practices of possible “traffic hijacking”, i.e. un-authorized use of (pieces of) third-party content to fuel reach.

BE

Based on management’s financial targets, i.e. 30% sales CAGR 2016-2020, EBITDA break-even in 2018 and long-term EBITDA margins of greater than 20%, the transaction price implies a multiple of 11-21x 2020E EBITDA, assuming a steep and, in our view, highly ambitious margin ramp beyond 2018 to 10-20% – clearly not undemanding for an asset with the characteristics outlined above.

BE

It’s fair to say that the response to this one has been lukewarm.

BE

Or, if you prefer, “These Analysts Think a German is Nuts And Here’s Why”

BE

But let’s not head down that road.

11:11AM
BE

So. It’s an up day.

BE

FTSE ahead 122 points at 6031 at pixel

BE

Closing out the worst quarter since 2011, as I think the front page noted this morning.

BE

Though September hasn’t been that awful. About 3% down, against several months of sixes.

BE

Everything’s rallying. Should we get Glencore out of the way first?

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 88.25, up 8 (+9.97%), High: 91.23, Low: 83.70, Volume: 76.33m
BE

It struck me afresh this morning how dumb that IoD letter was.

BE

Company needs emergency cash call, so pulls one.

BE

So IoD has a public moan about pre-emption rights. Which is super, but rather ignores the fact that it was an emergency cash call.

BE

It’s like complaining about someone jumping the queue for the water fountain while ignoring that they’ve set themselves on fire.

BE

IoD’s just a glorified Pall Mall lunch club, isn’t it? Anyway, back to Glencore.

BE

Cazenove giving it a push today.

BE

We regard Glencore’s 43% share price fall on distressed credit concerns to be
excessive. At Glencore’s $16bn market cap, the shares imply a -$2bn equity
value for its Industrial assets, yet the realisable value of these assets alone
should exceed their $29bn debt. GLEN has $13bn of available liquidity to
refinance $6.4bn of bonds maturing by YE’16, and its bank debt has no
financial covenants. Despite its robust liquidity, we retain credit rating
concerns; at current prices, we estimate a $10bn shortfall at YE’16 to preserve
its BBB. At today’s commodity prices, we believe GLEN is undervalued on
fundamentals, but asset sales and/or an additional capital raise will be required
to ease credit concerns. We thus remain Neutral with a £1.50/sh YE’16 PT

BE

 Liquidity concerns overstated in our view: Since announcing a $10bn
debt-reduction plan on 7th Sept that included a $2.5bn equity raise, GLEN’s
CDS has risen to ~840bps and its share price has fallen 43%. We identify
low refinancing risk in 2015/16; GLEN has ~$13bn of liquidity and debt is
primarily long-dated bonds. GLEN’s $15bn revolving loan that supports its
Marketing activities has no financial covenants and carries no refinancing
risk until May’18, meaning concerns that GLEN may be forced to liquidate
$18bn of trading inventory are exaggerated, in our view.

BE

 Credit risk concerns are legitimate, but manageable: Preservation of a
credit rating greater than BBB- is fundamental to its business model, in our view. At
current prices, we estimate a $10bn shortfall at YE’16 to sustain the existing
BBB/Baa2, which rises to ~$15bn if commodity prices fall 5%. S&P and
Moody’s have stated asset disposals are expected to reduce group debt and
we expect will allow until H1’16 for remedies to be applied. We identify
upside to GLEN’s $2.0bn disposal target; we expect greater than $1bn from gold and
silver pre-payments, plus $750-800m of EBITDA on spot in Agriculture
could be worth ~$10bn if valued in line with recent transaction comps in
soft commodity trading.

BE

 Additional capital buffer required to eradicate credit concerns:
Downside risk will likely continue to dominate GLEN’s shares until it can
reinforce its capital base. Since disposals may not be complete until 2016,
further capital raise may be required to eliminate credit risks, in our view.
 Valuation support is emerging: At its $16bn mkt cap, we calculate
GLEN’s Industrial assets are valued at just 6.0x EV/EBITDA versus 7.2x
average for RIO, BHP and AAL ($4.5bn Industrial 2016E EBITDA on
spot). We believe the realisable value of GLEN’s entire Industrial assets
exceeds its ~$29bn debt; therefore a -$2.3bn implied market equity value for
these assets is too pessimistic. We retain our Neutral rating and £1.50/sh PT.

BE

And Macquarie, saying the same. I think this was out yesterday but they’ve sent it over this morning, so ………..

BE

Debt reduction plan needs to be augmented by +$4bn under spot prices.
When we upgraded GLEN to O/P three weeks ago, we were comfortable that
the credit metrics were safe under spot prices at the time but highlighted that
a meaningful move down (~8%) in the basket price could require additional
debt reduction initiatives. Since then, metal prices have moved progressively
lower without an offsetting move in producer currencies. At current spot
prices, GLEN would generate just $7.5bn in EBITDA ($9.9bn under base) and
FFO would fall to $6.1bn, forcing the credit metrics to the margin of the BBB
band, leaving the credit rating at risk of a downgrade. Under these conditions,
we estimate that at least ~ $4bn of additional debt reduction initiatives would
need to be announced to reassure the ratings agencies and the market that
GLEN is committed to defending its BBB rating. We believe there is scope to
make up this shortfall, however, should spot prices fall by 5%, the debt
reduction target would need to rise by an additional $5.0bn ($19bn in total).

BE

Fears of credit lines being withdrawn are overblown. The blow-out in
GLEN’s CDS spreads appear to be fuelling fears that credit lines could start
being withdrawn from the trading business. However, GLEN’s trading
business is funded predominantly by syndicated revolving credit facilities
amounting to $15.3bn, which the company refinanced in June 2015. Only
$6.5bn of this had been drawn by mid-year and we are not aware of any
technical triggers – related to credit rating or debt covenants – which could
lead to funding being withdrawn. Moreover, the lending banks have very little
naked exposure as the company posts 100% collateral for every trade

BE

Stock implying another ~8% leg down in commodity prices. Reducing the
spot commodity price deck by 8% and applying peer group multiples to Mining
and Trading EBITDA yields an equity value close to £0.70/sh. In contrast, our
base case price deck suggests an equity value closer to £1.80/sh. Where the
stock ultimately ends up trading will therefore largely depend on the market’s
confidence that GLEN will defend its BBB rating but also on sentiment
towards commodity prices.

BE

(@fjp73: was that a rhetorical question? Because this is.)

BE

Meanwhile, CLSA continues to seek an analogy for Glencore

BE

Yesterday it was LTCM, today it’s MF Global.

BE

But it’s not Lehman.

BE

This is Mike Mayo, of course.

BE

Glencore is not Lehman or Long-Term Capital. First, the interest rate
market is 250x bigger than the commodities market. Second, its
exposures seem manageable for US banks. Third, US banks are better
equipped to withstand disturbances. Versus 1997 (Long-Term Capital),
banks have 5x more cash and 4x more capital. This scenario seems well
less than the Fed’s annual stress test. In sum, large bank estimates
remain at risk going into 3Q15 and secondary effects are tough to predict.
Yet, events such as this have the potential to further show the resiliency
of the industry per our theme “Utility banking” – ie, regulation hurts
growth but helps in times such as this.

BE

Direct bank exposure
Banks do not disclose exposures to Glencore but we do not expect outsized
exposures when banks likely report on this in a couple weeks during
earnings. The most likely US bank exposure relates to $15bn of credit lines
with banks ($6.6bn drawn as of mid-year), though this is likely spread among
over 20 banks, both domestic and foreign. Further, energy portfolios have
been heavily scrutinized by regulators and banks, making a large, undisclosed
outsized exposure to this sector extremely unlikely – ie, there are benefits
from extra regulation. The difference with Glencore’s total debt of $50bn also
relates to $31bn of capital-market notes that would likely be held by a range
of capital-market participants and investors, though this would be part of any
exposure analysis at US banks.

BE

The industry is more resilient
Our theme with Utility Banking is that growth is slower than in the past but
that the industry can absorb more unforeseen events, such as Glencore. This
may or may not be one more of these tests, but the industry can absorb a
body blow. Versus the period of Long-Term Capital (1997), the industry has
5x more cash ($1.8tn) and 4x more capital ($1.7tn). After size-adjusting the
industry’s balance sheet, the industry has $700bn more cash and $400bn
more equity versus this past period. In addition, the Fed’s stress test
assumes 10% unemployment, -6% GDP (one quarter), and the Dow at 8,700
before it allows banks to pay dividends or buy back stock. There are many
unknowns in a situation such as this but the industry is better positioned to
absorb them. If so, this may be yet one more example of the industry passing
a test that shows its improved strength.

BE

Loads of interesting stuff in there, as you’d expect.

BE

BE

But for another day, perhaps.

11:23AM
BE

……. Because @Mo’s bored with miners and wants us to talk supermarkets.

BE

Fair enough.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 259.90, up 30.6 (+13.34%), High: 263.00, Low: 250.50, Volume: 17.48m
BE

Raises FY guidance

BE

Post a very good Q2

BE

Now, there’s talk in the statement about price investment

BE

Anecdotally, I suspect Sainsbury — as the best-run of the big four — has been investing in the right places.

BE

As in, big stores have been getting cheaper while convenience has been getting more expensive.

BE

The former claws back share from the discounters while the latter provides the margin buffer.

BE

It’s a sensible approach. And it’s one I’d know more about if Sainsbury still hosted its annual backgrounder lunch, but perhaps for share-price reasons that seems not to happen any more.

BE

Caz to summarise.

BE

Sainsbury’s shares should reflect management’s upbeat tone vis a vis FY
consensus PBT expectations this morning. While we note that 2Q LFLs
were in line with expectations on easier comps (the 2-Y LFL worsened)
and that 3Q LFLs and 1H profits both face tougher comps, we wait for the
conference call in order to have some reassurance on the main factors
behind management’s increased outlook visibility.
 2Q highlights: 2Q LFLs were in line with expectations at -1.1% on a
base of comparison 170bp easier. We note that the 2-Y LFL worsened by
70bp to -3.9% from -3.2%. Both volume and transactions grew as the
decline in average basket continued to stabilize. The only detail we have
for now is clothing total sales of +13% (from +5% in the previous
quarter). Assuming non food of 15% of total sales ex fuel and non-food
LFL’s of 5%, the core estate would be running at -2% LFLs. Groceries
online orders grew at over 15% (no disclosure in 1Q). ‘The market is
clearly still challenging, with food deflation impacting many categories’.
 Guidance: following that both sales and cost savings are ahead of
management expectations, Sainsbury is guiding to FY underlying PBT to
be moderately ahead of their published consensus (£548mn as of June).
We are at £512mn.

BE

And SocGen.

BE

SG view This publication is very encouraging at a time when we see growing concerns on
UK food retailers’ cost structure given the increase in the minimum wage. It demonstrates
the group’s stronger-than-expected flexibility on costs and strengthens our view that
Sainsbury’s profile is more resilient than many think thanks to its strong differentiation,
efficient marketing policy and good execution in stores. The valuation looks attractive, with
a 2016e P/E ratio of c10x.

BE

Various mentions of the Sainsbury short position, which might well be a factor this morning.

BE

Though I was never totally clear how much the big short position in Sainsbury was rehypothecation.

BE

UBS too.

BE

Market conditions currently favourable with prices flat to up month on month
Though year on year deflation is currently taking the shine out of the trading
performance, our price scrape data suggests that prices are currently flat to up (ASDA
in particular seems to be nudging prices up). Challenges remain of course and the
‘moderately ahead’ comment assumes ‘current market trends continue’. But to guide
profit up at the H1 stage suggests confidence in the outlook.
The best performing of the Big 4 is the best differentiated
Within the detail of the release, there are some indications of what’s going better than
expected; simplifying the offer is delivering lower than expected levels of waste and
strong clothing sales (up c13%) likely help as they carry a good margin. Better trading
though definitely helps and we think it’s no coincidence that the best performing of the
Big 4 is also the best differentiated. The price focused in contrast (notably ASDA with a
LFL down near 5%) are more likely to be undermined by the growth of the discounters.

BE

On low multiples (a P/E of less than 11x, EV/EBIT at 10x and double digit free cash flow yield) the last thing the shares expect is an upgrade. High short-interest could further amplify the share reaction which we think will be positive. Our 330p PT (up from 325p) is based on a sector like 12x EV/EBIT multiple for the retail business (was 12.5x). Sainsbury’s
reports H1 profit on 11 November – we pencil in £285m of underlying PBT.

BE

(@R7039275: by memory, about 20% of free float. I’d check, but the machine’s three desks away.)

11:34AM
BE

Oh, should just mention the rest of the sector ……..

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 167.10, up 11 (+7.05%), High: 167.20, Low: 160.40, Volume: 5.74m
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 180.70, up 9.4 (+5.49%), High: 180.90, Low: 174.70, Volume: 9.65m
BE

Thinking good news from Sainsbury suggests good news for Morrison seems irrational to me. Whatever though.

11:35AM
BE

Rocket H1′s noted on the right. Haven’t had time to go through them myself.

BE

Up 14% though, so I guess there must be something good in there.

BE

Okay, so weighted average H1 15 revenues/GMV were up 142% YoY for Proven Winners

BE

EBITDA margin up by 6 ppts.

BE

Cazenove sounds pleased.

BE

Essentially, revenues for almost every Proven
Winner were better than expected (with Jumia, Zalora and Linio well
ahead of JPMe). EBITDA margins of Proven Winners were also better
than expectations, showing an improvement both YoY and compared to
Q1 15, which we see positively. Linio and Jumia EBITDA margins were
notably better than expected, while Namshi was close to breakeven with
EBITDA margin of -3%.

BE

Last Portfolio Value (LPV) has increased by €1.2bn since the end of
April. At Q1 15, Rocket had reported LPV of €4.8bn and cash of €1.2bn
at holding level, a €2.3bn uplift in LPV since IPO. Rocket Internet now
states it has increased its Last Portfolio Value by €3.4bn since the IPO in
October 2014.

BE

In our view, use of cash and understanding the path to profitability
and timing are the most important catalysts for the stock: We think
questions at the Capital Markets Days today will focus on 1) whether
there any examples of companies profitable within any territory now, 2)
the sources and uses of cash from IPO to now and especially how much
has been cash absorbed by the operations of group companies, 3) how
the company intends to invest cash on hand (M&A vs increasing stakes
vs funding operating losses) and whether it is likely to raise further
capital, 4) any targets.

BE

Hm.

BE

Seems the presentation wasn’t quite enough to win over Neil Campling at Aviate

BE

Who notes the CEO seemed rather reticent to talk about the churn rate and life cycle of a subscriber at Hello Fresh

BE

Too commercially sensitive. Apparently.

BE

Let me get some of Campling, though you really need to do yourself a favour and get on his list yourself.

BE

The CMD today by Rocket is focused on providing greater transparency, with the move to IFRS accounting cited as the commitment to the same. Company commit to prime standard accounting in Germany within the next twelve months and set nine key targets to be measured against. But two of these are likely the main reason for today’s short squeeze and relief rally: namely the promise of no significant M&A transaction and commitment to no dilutive capital issuance in the next three years at the group level (which is hardly necessary given the recent convert transactions).

But within business operations themselves, which frankly is what it all comes down to long term, we continue to see concerns about the most important drivers for such a perceived hyper growth based Internet business model. Namely we continue to see evidence of Slowing growth in many of the businesses.

BE

In GFG (Global Fashion Group) where we had previously highlighted issues in India, note this India franchise Jabong has slowed considerably. In fact order growth has turned NEGATIVE. Total QoQ orders fell from 1.4m in Q1 2015 to 1.3m in Q2 2015, and GMV only grew 2.7% QoQ. It’s not only the Jabong component of GFG exhibiting less than exponential growth. At Dafiti active users (defined, according to the prospectus, as having made at least one order in the last 12 months – an eternity in the Internet economy) slowing considerably from 57% in 2013 to 31% in 2014, 26.6% in H1 2015 and turned negative QoQ from 2.4m to 2.3m in Q2 2015. At La Moda the active user growth +160% in 2013 slowed to 56% in 2014 and then 40% in H1 2015. LaZarda is burning cash, posting a -124% EBITDA margin in H1 2015 and burning US$80m in three months suggesting the company will have to tap a third party investor in the next six to nine months.

Hello Fresh EBITDA is stabilizing on a constant basis. But that is at a negative -18% adjusted EBITDA margin. Numbers at Hello Fresh were out last week so there is little incremental information this morning.

Delivery Hero, at the cornerstone of the GTAG (Global Take Away Group) is SLOWING considerably. Less information is being made available relative to the last update but we now know H1 2015 revenues grew 154% YoY, whereas it grew 201% YoY in Q1 2015. And this is unaudited management accounts so we are unable to strip out if this is inflated further by acquisitions. And order growth of 87% QoQ outpaced revenue growth of 50% QoQ which should concern. But whereas the Rocket event earlier this year focused considerably on the GTAG Group back in March, this event today has excluded it as a standalone presentation even though there are 11 separate presentations. Poetic license perhaps?

BE

A considerable lock up expiry at Rocket happens, by chance, to be Friday. So perhaps it is little wonder to see a charm offensive, focused CMD event today in London (and the same tomorrow in NYC). It is also worth remembering the current stock option plan too. There are two principal requirements of the share participation plan for the Management Group. First, Rocket must successfully launch four companies per year during the four year period post IPO. So, to be clear that’s successfully starting a company, not for a launched company to be successful in any quantifiable way. They are clearly off to a good start, as Rocket has confirmed they are on track to launch 10 companies this year, having already launched nine companies YTD. Second, the stock price over the four year period must reflect a valuation of Rocket of €4 billion. But not over a number of weeks or months. For just one day over the four years.

All told, given the signs of slowing growth in a number of ‘proven winners’ and difficulties in valuing/evaluating the terminal values of the LPV constituents we see a significant short squeeze as an opportunity to add to shorts.

BE

Heh. Didn’t realise the lockup expiry. Freaky coincidence, that.

11:43AM
BE

What else? Oh, had a few worried punters around this morning in BG

BE

Spread against Shell’s been blowing out again.

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,554, up 11 (+0.71%), High: 1,568, Low: 1,552, Volume: 3.70m
BG Group PLC (BG.:LSE): Last: 950.10, up 0.5 (+0.05%), High: 965.80, Low: 948.10, Volume: 5.92m
BE

Now looking at a 125p bid spread or thereabouts.

BE

Now, Shell’s been hosting meetings investor lately and the message remains, apparently, that the transaction will be free cashflow positive.

BE

Arbs tell me the spread’s widening because folk are selling BG rather than covering their Shell shorts.

BE

Which has led to speculation that there’s just a big seller of BG in the market right now, which is what’s causing the widening spread.

BE

Apparently. This is what I’m told. Dunno how much consensus bias there is in that reading.

11:49AM
BE

Oh, should also say that Olivetree have been on top of the Shell-BG arb so if you’re worried, talk to them.

BE

There. Done.

11:50AM
BE

(@TheLeggie: I’d tend to agree. Buying BG is better than a rights issue, which is the alternative.)

BE

Hm. What else can we note? Melt-up days are the worst.

BE

Someone was pushing HSBC, I think. Possibly UBS.

BE

Yes. UBS.

BE

Since August 11th when the PBOC unexpectedly weakened the RMB HSBC’s share price
has fallen 15-20%, equivalent to a decline of almost US$30bn in market cap. We
believe the market has de-rated the Asian franchise to a multiple of just 1.2x tangible
book for a business that we expect to make a 16% RoTE this year. The headline yield of
6.8% (5% post scrip), which appears sustainable, also now provides support. The
relative risk/reward balance on the shares has shifted to the upside in our opinion so we
upgrade to Buy with a 550p (HK$65) price target.

BE

We continue to believe that within the HSBC group there are a number of attractive,
high return businesses (commercial/retail banking in Asia/UK). Large proportions of the
group’s capital (perhaps as much as 50%) are also earnings sub-par returns at present.
We see considerable scope for further group restructuring to free up capital and shrink
the business back into its higher return footprint. A tougher macro backdrop may even
accelerate this process. Post years of de-risking we view the group’s high return
businesses as “liability” driven which gives them leverage to rising rates in both the
UK/US. Little of this potential upside seems to be reflected in the current share price.

BE

The group still faces numerous headwinds. Almost a decade of de-leveraging has led to
a significant reduction in group sustainable RoE & the regulatory backdrop continues to
shift. RWA inflation remains a concern. We believe this is likely to offset some of the
benefit of the group’s targeted US$290bn RWAs reduction target. There is also still a
considerable tail of litigation risk the group faces and our forecasts do not anticipate
the group meeting its US$32bn 2017 exit run-rate on costs.

BE

Our SOTP-based price target for HSBC is lowered to 550p (HK$65) from 595p. This
reflects the earnings downgrades and a lowering of the multiple applied to the group’s
Asian business to 1.6x tangible book from 1.8x). We expect a broadly flat dividend
which gives the stock a post scrip yield of c5%. While there are headwinds and limited
obvious catalysts in the short term we do now see value in the shares. We upgrade our
rating to Buy from Neutral.

BE

(@roddy1234: yup, would’ve been great to livecast from the CMD today. Sadly, what with yesterday’s power cut disruption and today’s staffing being down 50%, we are limited to doing what we can.)

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 496.15, up 10.6 (+2.18%), High: 498.10, Low: 486.74, Volume: 10.00m
11:54AM
BE

Darty? To be totally honest, I forgot it existed.

Darty PLC (DRTY:LSE): Last: 94.44, up 13.44 (+16.59%), High: 95.25, Low: 92.50, Volume: 5.48m
BE

And soon, it won’t. Fnac bid value of about 100p a share.

BE

As in one Fnac share per 39 Darty shares, which was a 27% premium pre open.

BE

Less a divi of 2.625c per share

BE

Due November 13.

BE

And a Panel deadline of 28 October to firm things up.

BE

No regulatory angle, really, which is a surprise in France.

BE

Here’s Caz.

BE

The electricals market in France is more fragmented
than that in the UK for example. We estimate that Darty has a market
share of c.15% in France, versus Dixons in the UK with c.30%.
Combining two of the leading French players, in our view, would therefore
be sensible, particularly given the highly commoditized and competitive
nature of the category. Fnac has commented that it believes a deal would
offer “significant synergies”. Our first take is therefore that there is a high
chance of the acquisition taking place.

11:59AM
BE

Is that midday yet? There always seems to be too much news or not enough.

BE

Today’s been the latter.

BE

Nothing much to add for E1′s purchase of the rest of Astley Baker Davies

BE

As in, the creator of Peppa Pig

BE

Reasonably profitable business, in spite of my scepticism about pre-school IP.

BE

Revenues are generated predominantly through royalties paid by
licenses via several categories such as toys and clothing, as well as
DVDs and other ancillary revenues. The business (vast majority of
eOne’s family operations) achieved c.£22m of EBITDA in 2015 (or 20%
of Group EBITDA) for its 50% share. Through the acquisition, eOne
will increase its share of earnings from the exploitation of Peppa Pig
from 50% to 85% and the Group will be fully consolidated.

BE

(Caz, again.)

BE

Which hasn’t rejigged its figures for the rights issue yet, but …..

BE

We assume the acquisition to be earnings accretive from 2018/19.
Clearly, the amount of accretion will depend on eOne’s market cap at the
time of the proposed equity issue. We expect broadly c4% EPS dilution
in FY 16E and c8% dilution in FY 17E.

BE

Anyway, that’s that.

BE

And that’s us.

BE

(@fjp73: Peppa Pig is not the merchandised version of Winnie the Pooh. That’s an appalling analogy on any number of levels.)

BE

Thanks for joining. I’ll see you tomorrow, as might Paul.

BE

Possibly.

BE

(No refunds.)
